Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Enforcing Pollution Regulations in Authoritarian Regimes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Summary

This research project explains how authoritarian countries enforce pollution regulation. Moreover, this research examines the interactions between national and subnational institutions as they relate to enforcement of pollution regulation. This project examines how two major institutions have created divergent incentives structures for local bureaucrats that produce the following research questions: 1) Does the fact that budget-poor bureaucrats are dependent on polluting firms make budget-poor bureaucrats more likely to defy the central authority and protect polluters than their budget-rich counterparts?; 2)Do state ownership of firms make it easier for local officials to obtain compliance from certain polluters? By highlighting the impact of state institutions on bureaucratic behavior, this project draws attention to under-explored structural explanations for why government agents systematically defy-or obey-government leaders. It also examines the tools and strategies authoritarian leaders use to confront emerging governance crisis.

Technical Summary

This research project explains how authoritarian countries enforce pollution regulation. Moreover, this research examines the interactions between national and subnational institutions as they relate to enforcement of pollution regulation. Using China as the case of interest, this project draws on case study research and statistical analysis to ascertain when officials in China's 283 prefecture-level cities choose to punish-or protect-polluters. The quantitative component uses two original datasets to test for key variables associated with weak enforcement of pollution regulation in China: First, using NASA satellite data, the PI compiles a database on the level of pollution violations in 283 cities. Second, to assess how firm ownership affects pollution enforcement, the PI compiles data on individual firm characteristics of all major polluting firms in the 283 cities. The PI project then uses interview research with regulators (local officials) and the regulated (polluting firms) to explain the patterns revealed by quantitative data. Interviews are conducted in two regions of China with contrasting records on pollution to understand how incentives to enforce pollution regulation may vary in these two regions. The PI focuses on the motivations of individual officials and factory owners. This study provides important understanding on the incentive structure that regulates administrative behavior in authoritarian regimes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examines the rise of ‘blunt force’ pollution regulation in China. In a challenge to existing studies, this project proposes that Chinese officials are willing to sacrifice economic growth to reduce pollution. However, instead of punishing polluters through stated environmental laws and regulations, local officials are resorting to intrusive, ‘blunt force measures’ such as cutting off electricity to entire industries or forcing polluting firms to close or relocate. Using satellite data on pollution and an original dataset on municipal enforcement tools, the researcher shows that blunt force regulation has become the predominant policy tool for reducing pollution in China’s prefecture-level cities.

China’s widespread use of blunt force regulation is puzzling: compared to conventional enforcement tools (such as pollution fines and fees) blunt force regulation decimates local employment and undermines already weak regulatory institutions. If local officials can take such drastic action against polluting firms, why are they not using their considerable authority and political will to enforce existing environmental regulations? Why are they choosing instead to close down firms at enormous cost to local revenue and employment?

To find answers to this puzzle, the researcher conducted a series of interviews with Chinese officials, firm owners and citizen activists over a six-month period. Based on these interviews, the researcher proposes that China’s combination of strong authority over market actors but weak administrative capacity has pushed them towards this suboptimal ‘blunt force’ solution. Under pressure from Beijing, local officials are motivated to reduce pollution but they lack the capacity to repeatedly monitor, fine or follow-up on violators. In contrast, blunt force measures require far less information gathering, especially when applied to all firms in a targeted industry (including compliant firms). Using data, case studies, and insights from interview research, the researcher shows how blunt force regulation provides normally weak regulators with powerful levers of control over firms—including the authority to abruptly close or suspend operations. These ad hoc powers not only help regulators sidestep everyday capacity limitations but also allow them to selectively implement punitive measures, often by targeting weaker firms or the informal workforce. Thus, by using extreme measures to politicize regulation, local officials can ensure that pollution is reduced while minimizing social or political opposition. In short, blunt force regulation, while inefficient, provides a feasible shortcut to meeting Beijing’s demands while protecting key local interests.

This project addresses an enduring question in political science: in weak institutional environments, how can political leaders push through policies that challenge powerful local interests? Current debates point to the importance of societal participation; states with weak institutional capacity can draw on the media and citizen activists to expose implementation failures or to increase public pressure on non-compliant actors. These theories imply that to overcome its current regulatory challenges, China needs to expand its channels for public feedback. However, this project shows that against the trend in other developing countries, China is attempting to fix its regulatory problems without widening the space for public participation. In fact, it is turning to intrusive, top-down measures that rely on increasing state control over the economy. Is China developing a viable regulatory alternative with its blunt force approach? Or is it coming up against the limits of this model? As pollution becomes one of the most urgent governance problems of our generation, this project examines whether a state-centered approach to regulation is a reasonable option for controlling polluters in weak institutional environments.

For more general audiences, this project draws attention to the unusual strategies China is using to reduce pollution. Existing news coverage of China’s pollution problems tend to focus on public health failures, or failures to enforce environmental laws. This leads to the view that Chinese leaders almost always prioritize the economy over the environment. In fact, this project shows that China’s municipal leaders are taking drastic action to reduce pollution, but they are doing so through unprecedented, extra-legal measures. This means that mainstream coverage of China’s efforts to tackle pollution are missing one half of the picture—and a half picture that is transforming industries and labor markets around China. This project aims to address this gap in our knowledge by analyzing the impact—and limits—of China’s blunt force approach to cleaning up the air.
